snippet: Advocates say a “no” vote on the treaty could hurt Ireland’s ability to borrow internationally, while opponents say the pact’s limits on deficits and debt could prolong Ireland’s slump.
abstract: Irish voters are skeptical as referendum approaches on a new European financial treaty intended to ensure stability and sustain the country's ability to borrow internationally; critics of the treaty argue that its limits on deficits and debt could prolong Ireland's economic slump. (M)a
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN -- Once again, a major European treaty is being put before Irish voters in a referendum. Once again the government is asking them to set aside their misgivings and give the treaty their blessing, in a five-week publicity campaign that started on Monday. And once again the voters may be in no mood to go along. Prime Minister Enda Kenny said Monday that a ''yes'' vote in the May 31 referendum was ''absolutely critical'' for job creation in Ireland, hoping to strike a chord in a country with 14 percent unemployment and from which an average of 1,000 people a week are emigrating to find work.

headline.main: European Financial Treaty Faces Skeptical Irish Voters in Tough Referendum Fight
